author: Lia Eustachewich
title: B&B owners kept disabled man in barn while stealing his social security: cops | New York Post
text:
Owners of an Orange County bed-and-breakfast kept a mentally disabled man in a barn for years while they drained his bank account, police said Wednesday.
The victim, Joseph Polizzi, worked as a farmhand for John and Mary Quick at Silent Farm in the sleepy town of Goshen for 18 years in exchange for free room and board, a State Police spokesman said.
The Quicks are accused of siphoning Polizzi’s social security benefits from his bank account – though police are working on determining exactly how much was stolen.
“This is still a lengthy investigation,” spokesman Steven Nevel told The Post.
Polizzi, 59, began living on the 80-acre horse farm 10 years ago – but a tipster alerted Orange County social service workers that he was living in “deplorable” conditions and was having his social security benefits withheld, Nevel said.
That led police to discover Polizzi was being housed in a small room in front of one of the barns, without heat or running water.
Polizzi hasn’t had control of his bank account since 2005, cops said.
John and Mary Quick were arrested earlier this month on charges of grand larceny and endangering the welfare of a vulnerable adult.
Phone numbers for Silent Farm and Mary were out of service.
John couldn’t be reached for comment.
